raw_text:
Camera phones are 'must-haves'
 
 Four times more mobiles with cameras in them will be sold in Europe by the end of 2004 than last year, says a report from analysts Gartner.
 
 Globally, the number sold will reach 159 million, an increase of 104%. The report predicts that nearly 70% of all mobile phones sold will have a built-in camera by 2008. Improving imaging technology in mobiles is making them an increasingly "must-have" buy. In Europe, cameras on mobiles can take 1.3 megapixel images. But in Japan and Asia Pacific, where camera phone technology is much more advanced, mobiles have already been released which can take 3.2 megapixel images. Japan still dominates mobile phone technology, and the uptake there is huge. By 2008, according to Gartner, 95% of all mobiles sold there will have cameras on them.
 
 Camera phones had some teething problems when they were first launched as people struggled with poor quality images and uses for them, as well as the complexity and expense of sending them via MMS (Multimedia Messaging Services). This has changed in the last 18 months. Handset makers have concentrated on trying to make phones easier to use. Realising that people like to use their camera phones in different ways, they have introduced more design features, like rotating screens and viewfinders, removable memory cards and easier controls to send picture messages.
 
 Mobile companies have introduced more ways for people to share photos with other people. These have included giving people easier ways to publish them on websites, or mobile blogs - moblogs. But the report suggests that until image quality increases more, people will not be interested in printing out pictures at kiosks. Image sensor technology inside cameras phones is improving. The Gartner report suggests that by mid-2005, it is likely that the image resolution of most camera phones will be more than two megapixels. Consumer digital cameras images range from two to four megapixels in quality, and up to six megapixels on a high-end camera. But a lot of work is being done to make camera phones more like digital cameras. Some handsets already feature limited zoom capability, and manufacturers are looking into technological improvements that will let people take more photos in poorly-lit conditions, like nightclubs. Other developments include wide-angle modes, basic editing features, and better sensors and processors for recording film clips.
 
 Images from camera phones have even made it into the art world. An exhibition next month in aid of the charity Mencap, will feature snaps taken from the camera phones of top artists.
 
 The exhibition, Fonetography, will feature images taken by photographers David Bailey, Rankin and Nan Goldin, and artists Sir Peter Blake, Tracey Emin and Jack Vettriano. But some uses for them have worried many organisations. Intel, Samsung, the UK's Foreign Office and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories in the US, have decided to ban camera phones from their buildings for fear of sensitive information being snapped and leaked. Many schools, fitness centres and local councils have also banned them over fears about privacy and misuse. Italy's information commissioner has also voiced concern and has issued guidelines on where and how the phones can be used. But camera phone fears have not dampened the manufacturers' profits. According to recent figures, Sony Ericsson's profits tripled in the third-quarter because of new camera phones. Over 60% of mobiles sold during the three months through to September featured integrated cameras, it said.
llama3.2:1b: Camera phones will sell 159 million by the end of 2004 globally and nearly 70% of all mobiles will have built-in cameras by 2008. The number of camera phones is expected to double in Europe from last year to reach 160 million. Japan dominates mobile phone technology, but other countries are catching up with 95% of their sales having cameras on them by 2008. Improving imaging technology has improved image quality, making them more useful for general use. Camera phones have become a must-have item, and manufacturers continue to improve features such as zoom capability, editing, and sensors.
llama3.2:3b: Camera phones will reach 159 million global sales by 2004, with nearly 70% of all mobiles having a built-in camera by 2008. Camera phone technology has improved significantly, allowing for better image quality and increased functionality such as rotating screens and viewfinders. The industry is also exploring technological improvements to let people take photos in poorly-lit conditions and editing features.
gemma2:2b: Camera phones sales are rapidly increasing globally, predicted to reach 159 million by 2004 and likely exceeding 70% of all mobile phone sales by 2008.  Improvements in image technology, ease of use, and increased sharing options have made camera phones "must-haves". While Japan leads the field with advanced camera technologies, Europe is catching up. Manufacturers are introducing more features to improve usability and share photos easily. However, concerns about privacy and misuse are prompting bans from some organizations. Despite this, manufacturers are seeing strong profits due to camera phone sales.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Camera phones are becoming more popular as mobile technology advances. Four times more devices with cameras will be sold by the end of 2004 than in 2013, according to Gartner. Mobile cameras take high quality images up to 6 megapixels (8 megapixels at higher resolutions), but only a small percentage have built-in cameras (around 7%). Japan and Asia-Pacific are already using camera phones with more advanced sensors. Handset makers like Sony Ericsson are developing new features for mobile phones, such as wider viewfinder screens, removable memory cards, and easier control to send picture messages. Camera phones are also making it into the art world, with an exhibition next month featuring images taken from top artists' camera phones. Concerns have been raised about camera phone use affecting people's privacy. Many organizations, including Italy's information commissioner, have banned camera phones in their buildings as a way of protecting sensitive information.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Camera phones will see explosive growth worldwide by 2008, with Europe leading the market; companies are improving features and image quality, but concerns about privacy and security persist.
qwen2.5:3b: Camera phones are expected to be widely adopted with a significant increase in Europe by the end of 2004 compared to last year, reaching 159 million units globally, and almost half of all phones will have built-in cameras by 2008. Japan leads adoption, with over 95% of sold phones featuring cameras. Initially faced with poor image quality and complexity issues, camera phones now offer more features like rotating screens, viewfinders, and easier controls for sending images via MMS. Despite advancements in technology, concerns persist about the practicality of printing high-quality photos from camera phones. Artistic applications are emerging, but many organizations have imposed bans due to privacy concerns and risks associated with sensitive information leakage. Sony Ericsson has seen its profits triple because of new camera phone sales.
opencoder:1.5b: The report emphasizes the importance of camera phones in modern smartphones and their applications in today's digital world. It highlights how they can provide more convenient access to digital content, enhancing overall user experience. By focusing on the features and ease-of-use, manufacturers aim to make mobiles an increasingly popular choice for consumers.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and objective, capturing the main points from the original text while omitting unnecessary details. The key ideas and details are preserved, including:

1. Camera phones will be more widely available by 2004 than in 2003.
2. Improving imaging technology has made cameras on mobiles more appealing to consumers.
3. Handset makers have introduced more ways for people to share photos with other people.
4. The report suggests that until image quality increases, people will not be interested in printing out pictures at kiosks.
5. Camera phones are already used by many artists and photographers.
6. An exhibition next month will feature images taken from camera phones of top artists.
7. Some uses for them have worried many organizations.
8. The use of cameras on mobiles has also raised privacy concerns.
9. Italy's information commissioner has issued guidelines on where and how the phones can be used.
10. Camera phone profits have tripled in the third-quarter because of new camera phones.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about camera phones and their market trends. Let me read through the provided text first to understand the key points.

The report says that by 2004, camera phones will be sold four times more in Europe than last year, reaching up to 159 million units. Globally, they're expected to grow by 104%. In Japan and Asia Pacific, only about 70% of mobiles have cameras, but that number is predicted to rise to 95% by 2008.

Camera phones can take up to 3.2 megapixels in Japan, which was previously limited to less than a megapixel. Handset makers are focusing on making them easier to use with features like rotating screens and viewfinders. Mobile companies have introduced ways for people to share photos online or via mobile blogs, but image quality is still the big focus.

Image sensors are improving, with most devices likely having more megapixels now. There's talk about zoom capabilities, wide-angle modes, basic editing tools, and better sensors and processors, especially in poor lighting conditions.

Images from camera phones are used in art too, as seen in an aid event. However, some organizations like Intel, Samsung, the UK Foreign Office, and the US LNR have banned camera phones for privacy concerns, restricting use either at schools or local councils.

Overall, despite challenges, there's a strong demand for camera phones with improvements in image quality and usability.
</think>

Camera phones are expected to become indispensable by 2004, reaching four times more in Europe than last year. Globally, they will sell up to 159 million units, growing by 104%. Japan and Asia Pacific countries have a high percentage of mobile phones with cameras, while Europe already has sales topping the mark. Mobile companies are introducing features like sharing via blogs or online platforms. Image sensors are improving, with many devices now capable of higher megapixel counts. Images from camera phones contribute to art as well. However, some companies restrict their use for privacy reasons. Despite these challenges, camera phones are expected to gain profits due to increased sales and improved image quality.
tinyllama:1.1b: The report "Camera Phones: Must-Have Devices by End of 2004" by Garner Research predicts that nearly 70% of all mobile phones sold will have built-in cameras by 2008, with a total number sold reaching 159 million globally in Europe. Camera phone technology is increasingly becoming an essential feature for buyers, and major improvements are being made to improve the quality and features of these handsets. As people prefer more images to be printed or sent via mobile messaging services, image sensor technology has already advanced by two to four megapixels, and there is a growing interest in creating cameraphone artwork for an upcoming exhibition. Cameras on mobile phones are already being used in fitness centres and local councils for privacy concerns, but the report suggests they could be banned from some schools and fitness centres in Italy due to concerns about misuse. The manufacturers have reportedly seen significant profit growth due to the introduction of new camera phone technology during the third quarter of 2013.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The increasing use of mobile phones with built-in cameras has led to a booming market. Sales of these devices have gone up by an astonishing 104%. According to Gartner, nearly 70% of all mobiles sold worldwide will have a camera this year. As improved imaging technology becomes more common, the market is set to explode with even more innovative uses for these cameras. Images from camera phones have made it into the art world as well, with an exhibition set to take place next month featuring images taken from the cameras of top artists like Rankin and Nan Goldin. However, concerns about privacy and misuse have led some institutions to ban camera phones from their premises.
phi:2.7b: Camera phones are increasingly popular due to their improving image quality and design features such as rotating screens and removable memory cards. Mobile companies have also introduced more ways for people to share photos with other people, but until image quality improves further, printing out pictures at kiosks is not a popular option. The art world has even made use of camera phone images in an exhibition next month. However, some organizations like Intel, Samsung, the UK'S Foreign Office and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories have decided to ban them from their buildings due to concerns over sensitive information being leaked. Despite these fears, camera phones remain a popular "must-have" among mobile phone buyers.
orca-mini:3b: Camera phones are becoming increasingly popular, with more than four times as many mobiles with cameras in them expected to be sold in Europe by the end of 2004 compared to last year. By 2008, 95% of all mobile sales in Japan will have cameras on them, according to analysts Gartner. Camera phones have improved significantly since their launch, with handset manufacturers focusing on making them easier to use and more design features. Image sensor technology has also improved, allowing for camera phones to capture higher quality images than ever before. Some mobile companies are even exploring ways to make camera phones more like digital cameras, with features such as wide-angle modes and better sensors for recording film clips. While concerns have been raised about privacy and misuse, the popularity of camera phones has not dampened the profits of manufacturers. According to recent figures, Sony Ericsson's profits tripled in the third-quarter because of new camera phones.
hermes3:3b: Camera phones expected to be majority of European sales by 2004, growing globally with improved imaging quality and user features, potentially affecting art world and leading to privacy concerns in institutions.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Camera phones will be four times more common in Europe by 2004 than last year, with a 104% increase in sales worldwide, according to Gartner. By 2008, almost 70% of mobile phones will have built-in cameras, as imaging technology improves and makes them a "must-have" purchase. In Europe, 1.3 megapixel images can be taken; however, Japan and the Asia Pacific region already have 3.2 megapixel cameras on some mobiles. Issues such as poor image quality and complexity of using MMS have been addressed through design improvements and easier user interfaces. While concerns about privacy and misuse exist in certain sectors like schools and government buildings, camera phone sales have still driven profits for manufacturers like Sony Ericsson.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Sales of camera phones in Europe are expected to quadruple by the end of 2004, with global sales reaching 159 million, a 104% increase. By 2008, nearly 70% of all mobile phones sold will have built-in cameras, with Japan leading the market, where 95% of mobiles will include cameras. Initially, camera phones faced issues with poor image quality and high MMS costs, but improvements in usability, design, and sharing options have boosted their popularity. Advances in image sensor technology are expected to push most camera phones beyond two megapixels by mid-2005, with features like zoom, better low-light performance, and video recording being developed. Camera phone images have even entered the art world, with an exhibition featuring works by renowned artists. However, concerns over privacy and security have led some organizations and institutions to ban them. Despite these concerns, manufacturers like Sony Ericsson have seen significant profit increases, with over 60% of mobiles sold in late 2004 featuring integrated cameras.
stablelm2:1.6b: Camera phones are becoming increasingly necessary purchases due to improving imaging technology and design features introduced by handset makers. The number of mobiles with cameras in Europe is expected to rise from 40 million to over 100 million by the end of this year, while Japan leads the way with nearly 90% of all mobile phones having a built-in camera by 208%. Camera phone adoption has been hindered by early image quality issues and complexity. However, handset makers have improved user experience, introducing rotating screens, viewfinders, and ways to share photos on websites or blogs. By mid-2015, most camera phones' image resolution could surpass two megapixels. Meanwhile, consumer digital cameras range from 2 to 6 megapixels in quality. In art circles, images captured by camera phones have found their place. An exhibition of Fonetography will showcase artists' snaps taken with these devices, including David Bailey, Rankin, and Nan Goldin alongside photographers Tracey Emin and Jack Vettriano. Nonetheless, some uses of camera phones have raised privacy concerns among organizations such  as Intel, Samsung, the UK's Foreign Office, and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories in the US. Schools, fitness centers, local councils, and even countries like Italy have banned them over privacy fears and misuse concerns. Despite this, camera phone sales have still seen substantial growth. Sony Ericsson's profits tripled during the third quarter due to new camera phones.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Camera phones are rapidly becoming a "must-have" feature for mobile devices, with sales projected to surge by 104% globally and reach 159 million units by the end of 2004. This trend is driven by advancements in imaging technology, enabling camera phones to capture high-resolution images, from 1.3 megapixels in Europe to 3.2 megapixels in Japan and Asia Pacific. By 2008, nearly all mobiles sold worldwide are expected to have cameras.

Challenges encountered initially, such as poor image quality and complexity in sending MMS messages, have been addressed through improved design features like rotating screens, viewfinders, removable memory cards, and easier controls for picture messaging. Mobile companies have also facilitated photo sharing via websites and mobile blogs (moblogs).

Image sensor technology is improving, with Gartner predicting that by mid-2005, most camera phones will exceed two megapixels in resolution. Handset manufacturers are working on features like zoom capability for low-light situations, wide-angle modes, basic editing tools, and enhanced film clip recording to make camera phones more competitive with consumer digital cameras.

Camera phone imagery has even found its way into the art world, as evidenced by an upcoming exhibition featuring photographs from renowned artists like David Bailey, Rankin, and Nan Goldin. However, concerns about privacy and potential misuse have led several organizations to ban camera phones in their premises, including Intel, Samsung, the UK's Foreign Office, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories, Italy's information commissioner, schools, fitness centers, and local councils.

Despite these concerns, the proliferation of camera phones has significantly impacted manufacturers' profits; Sony Ericsson reported a tripling of third-quarter profits due to new camera phone models accounting for over 60% of total mobiles sold during that period.
